article.headline: Fox News host Chris Wallace: Trump campaign looks âsillyâ for not owning up to Tulsa rallyâs crowd size
article.body: Trump campaign adviser Mercedes Schlapp did her best to respond to Fox News host Chris Wallace on Sunday when he pressed her on the size of the presidentâs rally in Tulsa. But Wallace wasnât having it. “ âMercedes, please donât filibuster. Weâre showing pictures here, and it shows big, empty areas. Frankly, it makes you guys look silly when you deny the reality of what happened.â ” Wallace was pointing out the fact that Saturdayâs rally was hyped up by the campaign as having drawn more than 1 million requests for tickets. The arena, which holds about 19,200 people, only drew about 6,200, according to the Tulsa Fire Department. Schlapp explained that several Trump supporters were âworried about the protesters coming in,â but Wallace refuted that claim. âProtesters did not stop people from coming to that rally,â he said, pointing out that Trump often cites the size of his rallies as a gauge of support. âThe fact is, people didnât show up.â The upper section of the arena is partially empty as President Donald Trump speaks at the rally. Getty Schlapp then focused her attention on Biden, calling him a âfailed politician,â but again, that didnât stop Wallace for digging for answers on the no-shows. âYouâre shifting to a campaign speech, which has nothing to do with the attendance of the rally,â he said. Watch the exchange: iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Another explanation that some, like Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortz, latched on to is that teenage TikTok users and K-pop fans were reportedly behind the âmillionsâ of ticket requests ahead of the event. The youngsters supposedly pranked the administration by signing up but not showing. Brad Parscale, the man leading Trumpâs re-election efforts, denied the validity of those reports. âLeftists and online trolls doing a victory lap, thinking they somehow impacted rally attendance, donât know what theyâre talking about or how our rallies work,â he said. âRegistering for a rally means youâve RSVPed with a cell phone number and we constantly weed out bogus numbers, as we did with tens of thousands at the Tulsa rally, in calculating our possible attendee pool.â
